thread.title: Mortgage rates fall for the 2nd week in a row
thread.title_full: Mortgage rates fall for the 2nd week in a row

title: Mortgage rates fall for the 2nd week in a row
text:
By Crissinda Ponder â€¢ Bankrate.com 
Mortgage rates fell for the second consecutive week even as government bond yields increased ahead of the July 28-29 Federal Reserve meeting. 
The 10-year Treasury bond yield rose from 2.25% Tuesday to 2.28% Wednesday afternoon, according to CNBC. 
Additionally, not-so-great housing market data has left the mortgage industry somewhat uneasy. Demand, sales on the decline 
New, single-family home sales fell nearly 7% from May to June, according to the most recent data available from the U.S. Census Bureau and the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Last month's rate was 18.1% higher than the June 2014 rate, however. 
The average sales price for new homes sold in June was $328,700. 
Homebuyer demand has cooled over the past month or so, which could cause the growth of home prices to slow down in August, Redfin forecast in its inaugural Housing Demand Index. 
The sluggish-like housing climate worries Brett Sinnott, vice president of capital markets at CMG Financial in San Ramon, California. 
"You're seeing a huge fall-off in people buying houses overall; (we're) kind of turning into a bit of a renter nation," he says. 30 year fixed rate mortgage -- 3 month trend A look at this week's rates The benchmark 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell to 4.09% from 4.12%, according to Bankrate.com's July 29 survey of large lenders. A year ago, the rate was 4.28%. Four weeks ago, it was 4.19%. The mortgages in this week's survey had an average total of 0.22 discount and origination points. Over the past 52 weeks, the 30-year fixed has averaged 4.04%. This week's rate is 0.05 percentage points higher than the 52-week average. The benchmark 15-year fixed-rate mortgage fell to 3.27% from 3.3%. The benchmark 30-year fixed-rate jumbo mortgage fell to 4.05% from 4.12%. The benchmark 5/1 adjustable-rate mortgage fell to 3.22% from 3.24%. Weekly national mortgage survey Results of Bankrate.com's July 29, 2015, weekly national survey of large lenders and the effect on monthly payments for a $165,000 loan:
